G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy falls within the District Court’s monetary jurisdiction, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in Newton, Massachusetts.

Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.raw_text: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987)
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to act with reasonable care to avoid causing unnecessary harm to others (see *Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987)).
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the limits of duty based on foreseeability in premises liability, not on articulating a broad, general duty that "every person" must act with reasonable care to avoid unnecessary harm. Its key statement of duty is specific to landowners/proprietors and framed in terms of foreseeable harm. While consistent with general negligence principles, the case does not itself clearly establish the universal duty formulation stated in the proposition.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.relevant_excerpt: A landowner or proprietor is not an insurer of the safety of his patrons. "The test is 'foreseeable harm.' . . . The underlying duty in every case, however, is to exercise the care which the circumstances reasonably require." Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 642 (1961). Based on the evidence presented, there could be no reasonable difference of opinion as to the improbability of the incident which occurred.

Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.raw_text: Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498 (1968)
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant’s violation of Newton's leash law constitutes evidence of negligence under the principle of negligence per se (see *Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc.*, 353 Mass. 498 (1968)).
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: Adamian concerns a liquor-licensing statute (G.L. c. 138, § 69) and holds that violation of that criminal statute is some evidence of negligence toward those the statute is intended to protect. It does not discuss leash laws, animals, or municipal ordinances, nor does it articulate a general negligence-per-se rule that would necessarily extend to a city leash law. Citing Adamian specifically for the proposition that violation of Newton’s leash law is negligence per se misstates the scope and subject matter of the decision.
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: “A violation of a criminal statute is some evidence of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp. 267 Mass. 501, 516. Baggs v. Hirschfield, 293 Mass. 1, 3. Falvey v. Hamelburg, 347 Mass. 430, 434.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions were the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, as the sight and approach of his unleashed dog caused Plaintiff to take evasive action that resulted in her injury (see *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637 (1996)).
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The provided passage is a concurrence stating that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is, the court (including this concurring justice) concludes there is no proximate cause. The case is therefore being used here in the opposite way from the proposition: it rejects, rather than accepts, that the defendant’s acts or omissions were the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were caused solely and directly by the negligence of Defendant, without any contributory negligence on the part of the Plaintiff (*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (1988)).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that the jury found both the defendant and the decedent each 50% negligent and then holds that, as a matter of law, the defendant was not negligent at all. The court does not find that plaintiff’s damages were solely and directly caused by defendant’s negligence; instead, it concludes the defendant breached no duty and affirms judgment for the defendant. Thus, the case contradicts rather than supports the proposition of sole defendant negligence without plaintiff contributory negligence.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: "The jury found that the negligence of Toubiana and the negligence of the defendant each contributed fifty per cent to the resulting death... The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred. We are satisfied that, on the evidence, no such conclusion was warranted... It follows that the defendant’s failure to adopt either of those measures did not constitute negligence."

Rodriguez v. Cambridge Housing Authority.raw_text: Rodriguez v. Cambridge Housing Authority, 443 Mass. 697 (2005)
Rodriguez v. Cambridge Housing Authority.proposition: Non-economic damages including pain, suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life, in an amount to be determined by the Court (see *Rodriguez v. Cambridge Housing Authority*, 443 Mass. 697 (2005)).
Rodriguez v. Cambridge Housing Authority.support_reasoning: The case concerns the availability and proof requirements for negligent infliction of emotional distress damages against a public housing authority, not a general statement that a court will award non‑economic damages (pain, suffering, emotional distress, loss of enjoyment of life) in an amount to be determined by the court. Rodriguez analyzes when emotional distress damages are recoverable and how they must be corroborated, and then applies the statutory damages cap, but it does not stand for the broad proposition cited. Using it simply to assert generic availability of non‑economic damages is therefore inaccurate and overbroad.
Rodriguez v. Cambridge Housing Authority.relevant_excerpt: “As to the plaintiffs’ recovery of damages for emotional distress, the judgment of the Superior Court dismissing the plaintiffs’ complaint is reversed. Judgment shall enter on the verdicts on those claims, as modified by the reductions in damages, pursuant to G. L. c. 258, § 2, set forth in the Appeals Court opinion. … [Samuel] is entitled to recover emotional distress damages of $100,000 for that same incident … and Carmen is entitled to recover emotional distress damages of $22,800 for the home invasion on June 4.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages resulting from Defendant’s reckless disregard of public safety and violation of Newton’s leash law, consistent with Massachusetts law (see *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); *Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club, Inc.*, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 17 (1997)).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard concerns premises liability and the abolition of the invitee/licensee distinction, with a concurrence critiquing the treatment of trespassers. It does not address dog-owner liability, leash laws, or recovery of damages for reckless disregard of public safety. Therefore, citing Mounsey for the specific proposition about damages arising from violation of Newton’s leash law and reckless disregard of public safety is inaccurate and unsupported by this text.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club.raw_text: Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club, Inc., 44 Mass. App. Ct. 17 (1997)
Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages resulting from Defendant’s reckless disregard of public safety and violation of Newton’s leash law, consistent with Massachusetts law (see *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); *Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club, Inc.*, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 17 (1997)).
Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club.case_name: Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club, Inc.
Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club.support_reasoning: Zavras concerns whether a pre-injury release can bar claims for gross negligence in a dirt-bike racing context; it does not address municipal leash laws, dog-related injuries, or recovery for damages based on “reckless disregard of public safety” in that context. The holding is that a release does not bar claims for gross negligence and that the plaintiff’s claim based on the flagman’s gross negligence could go to a jury. Using Zavras as authority for recovery tied to violation of Newton’s leash law misstates its subject matter and holding.
Zavras v. Capeway Rovers Motorcycle Club.relevant_excerpt: “In view of this caution in Massachusetts and the persuasive authority elsewhere discouraging aggravated wrongdoing, we hold that the release did not exempt the defendant from liability for grossly negligent conduct. … The actions of the flagman, however, could be found by a jury to be grossly negligent, that is, to show ‘a want of even scant care.’ … The defendant’s motion for summary judgment should not have been granted with respect to the alleged gross negligence of the flagger.”
